story.text: Logbook of the World is a web-accessed database provided by the American Radio Relay League to implement a contact verification service among amateur radio operators. [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logbook_of_The_World wikipedia] [https://www.rickmurphy.net/trustedqsl.org/tQSL-documents/lotwspec.pdf pdf]

LoTW Statistics (2018)
1,000,003,855 QSO records entered
187,798,390 QSL records confirmed
112,824 Users registered
165,239 Certificates active
18,724,655 User files processed
Using LoTW, radio amateurs can claim and verify contacts made with other amateurs, generally for claiming credit for operating awards, such as DXCC.

After repeated attempts, the ARRL has been unwilling to accept change requests in the design of LoTW as it has been published, and we do not expect them to make any changes that would make it easier to establish a server-to-server link between LoTW and eQSL.cc. [http://www.eqsl.cc/qslcard/LOTWAnalysis.cfm post]
Started processing your New Certificate Request.

For call sign: K9OX
For DXCC Entity: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA (291)
For QSOs not before: 2013-02-08 00:00:00
For QSOs not after: <blank>

Your certificate request has been accepted. As the next step in the verification process, a verification code will be printed on a postcard and sent to you via USPS. We will send you another e-mail once your postcard is on its way.
If you do not receive that e-mail within 2 business days, please contact LoTW-help@arrl.org explaining the situation. Please NO NOT resubmit this request.

Your certificate request has been accepted. As the next step in the verification process, a verification code will be printed on a postcard and sent to you via USPS. We will send you another e-mail once your postcard is on its way.
If you do not receive that e-mail within 2 business days, please contact LoTW-help@arrl.org explaining the situation. Please NO NOT resubmit this request.

Logbook of the World (LoTW) is a web-accessed database provided by the American Radio Relay League to implement a contact verification service among amateur radio operators. Using LoTW, radio amateurs (hams) can claim and verify contacts (QSOs) made with other amateurs, generally for claiming credit for operating awards, such as DXCC.

Logbook of the World is a web-accessed database provided by the American Radio Relay League to implement a contact verification service among amateur radio operators. Using LoTW, radio amateurs can claim and verify contacts made with other amateurs, generally for claiming credit for operating awards, such as DXCC.

Logbook of the World is a web-accessed database provided by the American Radio Relay League to implement a contact verification service among amateur radio operators.
Using LoTW, radio amateurs can claim and verify contacts made with other amateurs, generally for claiming credit for operating awards, such as DXCC.

Logbook of the World is a web-accessed database provided by the American Radio Relay League to implement a contact verification service among amateur radio operators. [https://www.rickmurphy.net/trustedqsl.org/tQSL-documents/lotwspec.pdf pdf]

Logbook of the World is a web-accessed database provided by the American Radio Relay League to implement a contact verification service among amateur radio operators. [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logbook_of_The_World wikipedia] [https://www.rickmurphy.net/trustedqsl.org/tQSL-documents/lotwspec.pdf pdf]

After repeated attempts, the ARRL has been unwilling to accept change requests in the design of LOTW as it has been published, and we do not expect them to make any changes that would make it easier to establish a server-to-server link between LOTW and eQSL.cc.
